title: 111_hr1353
content: The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Full Disclosure Act" requires registration of securities. The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Full Disclosure Act" mandates that securities issued by Fannie Mae under certain subsections are not exempt securities under SEC laws. This applies to mortgage-backed securities and subordinate obligations. The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Full Disclosure Act" amends Section 311 of the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act to specify that securities issued or guaranteed by the corporation are not exempt securities under SEC laws. The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Full Disclosure Act" specifies that securities issued or guaranteed by the corporation are not exempt securities under SEC laws. Transactions involving the initial disposition of pooled certificates by an approved seller are exempt from certain provisions of the Securities Act of 1933. An approved seller is an institution approved by the corporation to sell mortgage loans in exchange for pooled certificates. The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Full Disclosure Act" allows approved sellers to exchange mortgage loans for pooled certificates, which are single class mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the corporation. These securities can be issued directly to the approved seller in exchange for the underlying mortgage loans. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act are amended to clarify the treatment of securities issued or guaranteed by Freddie Mac. Transactions involving pooled certificates acquired from the Corporation by approved sellers are exempt from certain provisions of the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act are amended to clarify the treatment of securities issued or guaranteed by Freddie Mac. Transactions involving pooled certificates acquired from the Corporation by approved sellers are exempt from certain provisions of the Securities Act of 1933. Definitions for approved seller and pooled certificates are provided in the amendment. The Securities and Exchange Commission may issue regulations related to this subsection. The Securities and Exchange Commission may issue regulations to carry out the purposes of this section and its amendments. The amendments will take effect after a 180-day period from the enactment of the Act, applying to fiscal years of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac starting after this period. LIMITATION ON REGISTRATION FEES. Amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 limits registration fees for applicants filing a registration statement subject to a fee to not exceed five percent of the target offsetting collection amount for the fiscal year. Fees for registration statements related to business combinations are excluded from this calculation. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 limits registration fees for applicants and will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
